instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3546: What is 820-3546? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.SSD_RESET_L: What is SSD_RESET_L? SSD_RESET_L is a signal that puts the SSD in reset mode when it is low. This means the SSD will not be accessible when this signal is asserted.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.SSD_PWR_EN: What is SSD_PWR_EN? SSD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip making the power rail for the SSD to turn on when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.SSD_RESET_CONN_L: What is SSD_RESET_CONN_L? SSD_RESET_CONN_L is a signal that goes to the SSD that will put it in RESET mode which will keep it from working, when SSD_RESET_L is present. _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3546</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Liquid damage, SSD not reading
threads.message: Got a 13" Retina board that had liquid damage 8 months ago the client said and now has a flashing folder. Tried a tester SSD and still got the flashing folder. After looking around the board some I see signs of corrosion that tells the story that most likely the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> pin on the speaker connector shorted out the whole rail as there is power to the SSD Switch for <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> but no <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>. Is there a good place to start looking, currently I'm just going by testing nasty looking components on the rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3546</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Liquid damage, SSD not reading
threads.message:
1) Voltage on pin 2 of <CHIP>U8070</CHIP> for <SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>?

2) Voltage on pin 5 of <CHIP>U8070</CHIP> for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD_FET</SIGNAL>?

3) What does L3700 look like? Measure in resistance? 

4) What voltage do you get at pin 3 of <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> for <SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, and pin 4 for <SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_CONN_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3546</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Liquid damage, SSD not reading
threads.message:
No Title

Pin 2 <CHIP>U8070</CHIP>: 3.242v

Pin 5 <CHIP>U8070</CHIP>: 3.335v

Resistance of L3700: 0.1 ohm

Pin 3 <CHIP>U3740</CHIP>: 3.284v

Pin4 <CHIP>U3740</CHIP>: 3.41v

Most of the board looks like this and I can't tell if its just poor Apple build quality or just pure nastiness but the board has no other issues (yet) so I'm still in the grey area about jumping to whether things like this are F'd :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3546</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Liquid damage, SSD not reading
